You can dye fabric with food coloring like that used in Skittles. Hair, too! But - the fabric must be animal fiber, like silk or wool. Cotton won't take this kind of color. Also, you need a mordant, an agent to help the color stay in the fibers. Vinegar does this fine for wool or silk. Soak your fabric in water with vinegar in it, then spot your Skittles all over it. A little heat will help the process.

If you want to tie-dye with water based food coloring, several drops into a container, and fill it up A LITTLE with water. Use a small towel to dap the color onto the shirt, then throw it into the dryer for at least 20 minutes.

Continue the process until the shirt is fully colored to desire. And keep throwing it DIRECTLY INTO THE DRYER, ON HOT. (This WILL stain your dryer, but the stains come out easily).

To wash the shirt, test it once on cold wash, look for fading, reapply color after drying in dryer.

Another spectacular fail at dying stuff.  To permanently dye fabric you have to do one or two things to ensure the color won't wash out.  They get fastest and easiest is to put whatever fabric you're trying to die into the clothes dryer or iron with a very hot iron.  Hint: this is why you never put a garment that you think that has a stain on it into the dryer.  This method literally bakes the dying or stain into the fibers.  The second method is to use salt or vinegar to set the dyes.  There are tons of Internet site that explain the second method.  The next time you try to die something with an unusual source, at least iron it and try to set the dye before you wash it.
